title: 111_hr2324
content: The Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009 may be cited as the "Gun Show Background Check" Act. The Gun Show Background Check Act of 2009 finds that approximately 5,200 gun shows are held annually in the US, where criminals and prohibited persons obtain firearms without background checks or records for tracing. The Act defines a gun show as an event with 50 or more firearms offered for sale, excluding individual sales. The Gun Show Background Check Act of 2009 exempts certain offers or exhibits of firearms from background checks if they involve less than 100 firearms and are conducted by private, not-for-profit organizations primarily for hunting activities. The Gun Show Background Check Act of 2009 exempts certain gun show vendors from background checks if they are not licensed under section 923 and exhibit, sell, or exchange firearms at gun shows. Gun show operators must be at least 21 years old and register to operate a gun show. Gun show operators must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms interstate, have not violated any laws, and register with the Attorney General, providing fingerprints and a photograph. Gun show operators must register with the Attorney General by providing fingerprints, a photograph, certifying they meet requirements, disclosing all material information, making no false statements, and paying a registration fee. Gun show operators must also notify the Attorney General in writing of the gun show details and vendors at least 30 days before the event. Before the gun show starts, the operator must inform the Attorney General about the event details and vendors. They need to verify vendors' identities with valid identification documents, have them sign a ledger with identifying information, and a notice outlining their obligations as vendors. The gun show operator must inform the Attorney General about the event and vendors before the show starts. Vendors need to provide valid identification, sign a ledger, and receive a notice outlining their obligations. The operator must also notify attendees of the requirements of the chapter. Records must be maintained to demonstrate compliance with regulations. Unlicensed individuals are prohibited from transferring firearms at a gun show without a background check. Unlicensed individuals are prohibited from transferring firearms at a gun show without a background check. Licensed dealers must record firearm details and notify parties of background check results to ensure compliance with regulations. Licensed dealers must submit a report to the Attorney General within 10 days of a firearm transfer, including details like make, model, and serial number. They must also retain records of the transfer without disclosing personal information of unlicensed parties involved. They must also retain records of the transfer without disclosing personal information of unlicensed parties involved. Additionally, penalties for knowingly violating subsections of section 932 include fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. The Attorney General may impose penalties for knowingly violating section 932, including fines up to $10,000, registration suspension or revocation, and imprisonment up to 5 years for subsequent convictions. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect gun show operators' records without a warrant to ensure compliance with firearm regulations. Additionally, reports of multiple sales at gun shows must be provided to the authorities. (e) Reports of Multiple Sales Assisted by Licensees at Gun Shows. Section 923(g)(3)(A) is amended to include providing notice with respect to sales. (f) Increased Penalties for Serious Recordkeeping Violations by Licensees. Section 924(a)(3) is amended to impose fines and imprisonment for false statements or violations of recordkeeping requirements. (g) Increased Penalties for Violations of Criminal Background Check Requirements.-- Section 924(a)(5) of the title is amended to increase penalties for violations related to criminal background check requirements. The amendment includes hiring additional personnel for inspection purposes. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire additional personnel to inspect gun shows and submit biennial reports to Congress on firearm sales at these shows. The section and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
